context: This paper presents laboratory experiments on the partition processes of aromatic hydrocarbons and C6–C10 n-aldehydes between air, aqueous solution and solid materials of different chemical composition (Sahara dust, diesel soot and urban aerosol particles) added to the solution. The selected organic compounds were previously detected in field snow samples (Fries et al., 2008; Sieg et al., 2008). Chemicals Two stock standard solutions (Neochema, Germany) were prepared in methanol containing 200mgL−1 of each analyte. One solution was composed of BTEX (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, o-xylene, m-xylene and p-xylene) and the other one of C6–C10 n-aldehydes. From these two stock standard solutions one working standard solution was prepared by dilution of the stock standard solution with ultrapure water (membraPure, Bodenheim, Germany) to a final concentration of 500μgL−1 for each compound. Working standard solutions were freshly prepared every 2weeks. Diesel soot was purchased from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST, Gaithersburg, MD, 2009) sold as Standard Reference Material 2975, Diesel Particulate Matter (Industrial Forklift).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene and aldehydes are both part of a study examining the partition processes of aromatic hydrocarbons and C6–C10 n-aldehydes in various environmental matrices. They are included in separate stock standard solutions for laboratory experiments, indicating they are both relevant to the analysis of organic compounds in environmental samples. However, there is no direct interaction or specific relationship discussed between ethylbenzene and aldehydes beyond their inclusion in the same experimental framework.
